data.question: What is the effect of anions on the self-assembly and interconversion of metallacyclophanes?
data.answer: Anions play a crucial role in the self-assembly and interconversion of metallacyclophanes, acting as templates that influence the formation of specific cyclic structures.

data.question: Which anions favor the formation of molecular squares with Ni(II) and Zn(II) ions?
data.answer: The tetrahedral anions [BF4]- and [ClO4]- favor the formation of molecular squares with Ni(II) and Zn(II) ions.

data.question: What is the role of [SbF6]- anion in the formation of molecular pentagons?
data.answer: The [SbF6]- anion leads to the exclusive formation of a molecular pentagon due to its size and shape, which is appropriate to occupy a cavity slightly larger than that of the square.

data.question: Can the molecular pentagon be converted to a square?
data.answer: Yes, the molecular pentagon can be converted to a square by adding an excess of [BF4]-, [ClO4]-, or [I]- anions to solutions of the pentagon.

data.question: Is the molecular square more stable than the pentagon?
data.answer: Yes, the molecular square is more stable than the pentagon, as evidenced by the facile conversion of the pentagon to the square under milder conditions.

data.question: Can [IO4]- anions replace [ClO4]- anions inside the cavity of a molecular square?
data.answer: No, larger tetrahedral anions such as [IO4]- cannot replace [ClO4]- inside the cavity, but the linear [Br3]- anion is capable of doing so.

data.question: Does the presence of [NO3]- anions lead to the formation of a molecular triangle?
data.answer: Yes, mass spectrometric data suggest the existence of a molecular triangle in the presence of [NO3]- anions.

data.question: Are anion-π interactions operative in dictating the outcome of reactions forming cyclic products?
data.answer: Yes, anion-π interactions may be operative in dictating the outcome of reactions forming cyclic products, as suggested by short distances between the centroids of tetrazine rings and the O/F atoms of encapsulated anions.
